awd_titl_txt: CC* Regional: Tribal Consortium Research Network
awd_abstract_narration:
Navajo Technical University (NTU) is one of the nation's leading tribal colleges and a leader in delivering academic and research programs for the region and for the Navajo Nation. Tribal colleges regularly work in cooperation and in collaborative organizations.  In 2017, NTU facilitated the development of a tribal consortium to build cooperative support and technology services.  The tribal consortium includes Navajo Technical University, Crownpoint, NM, Dine College, Tsaile, AZ, Tohono O'odham Community College (TOCC), Sells, AZ, and A:shwi College and Career Readiness Center (ACCRC), Zuni, NM. Although Native American students have access to cultural, language, vocational, and Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) programs, campus and student connectivity options are expensive and limited to cellular or broadband capacities below national standards. Students are not well connected to the internet and to the larger research and education community; there is a fundamental lack of internet connectivity with sufficient bandwidth to successfully participate in the ever-increasing opportunities of online courses and programs. This project improves campus network performance in support of education and research, by increasing external connectivity to each campus by connecting to NTU as a regional aggregator.

The project addresses distance education challenges by implementing an advanced wireless testbed to deliver homework gap solutions for local students and faculty leverages a strong existing regional relationship with the Northern Arizona University, a leader in tribal programs and services. The project emphasizes meetings to map needs to requirements, followed by design and training workshops, which benefit the regional Native American communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

CC* Regional: Tribal Consortium Research Network

�

Award #1925689

Navajo Technical University, Crownpoint NM

�

Outcomes Report

May 30, 2024

�

Navajo Technical University (NTU) is the largest (enrollment 1,860) and most technologically advanced tribal college or university (TCU) in the United States. NTU operates a campus network and a microwave point-to-point network for the surrounding community. It also supports Navajo Nation information technology collaborations in support of improving the quality of life for tribal members and makes constant improvements to external connectivity to support faculty and research projects. The NTU Tribal Consortium established a research infrastructure to support manufacturing, agriculture, science, information technologies, and mathematics at tribal colleges and universities in Arizona and New Mexico.� The tribal consortium includes leadership technical support from Northern Arizona University (NAU) Information Technologies Services and includes additional tribal colleges and universities not included in the NSF project, such as the Southwest Indian Polytechnic Institute (SIPI) and the Institute of American Indian Arts (IAIA).� The project consortium members include:

�

●����� Tohono O�odham Community College in Sells, Arizona (Tohono O�odham Nation, AZ)

●����� Din� College in Tsaile, Arizona (Navajo Nation, AZ)

●����� A:shiwi College and Career Readiness Center in Zuni, New Mexico (Zuni Pueblo, NM)

�

The Consortium established a TCU cooperative to discover and install improvements to external connectivity, plan and implement a science-oriented network on each campus and deploy a homework gap wireless option.� Each of the participating colleges identified new challenges and opportunities to NTU and NAU.�

�

Each of the consortium projects resulted in several anticipated and unanticipated outcomes.� The consortium encouraged each TCU to train, educate, integrate, and facilitate collaborations and partnerships to help prepare tribal colleges and universities for active participation and engagement in regional and national networking.� NTU and NAU worked with the Front Range GigaPoP (Denver, CO), Sun Corridor Network (Phoenix, AZ), and the University of New Mexico ABQ-GigaPoP (Gallup, NM) to identify connectivity options, middle and last mile services, and alternatives to building science-oriented networks.� In each case, NTU discovered that proposed or recommended connections to Internet2 �connectors� were unavailable or exceedingly expensive for the project.� Towards the end of the project, NTU reconciled connectivity by adding middle mile services between Dine College (Tsaile, AZ) and NTU (Crownpoint, NM) using recently installed fiber funded by CARES Act resources.� Until then, Dine College used multiple ISPs with multiple underlying technologies, and the use of a tribal utility that imposed a significant monthly expense.� Without the influx of significant federal broadband funding, Dine College options were limited and unavailable generally for science or dedicated connectivity.� After months of discussion with the Tohono O�odham internet service provider (ISP) community, TOCC was unable to secure any fiber alternative connection to Sun Corridor Network.� As a result of the tribal requirement to use a single commodity internet provider, TOCC and NTU resourced and implemented a Starlink satellite service for campus use exclusively and available to the project.� The Zuni Tribal community improvements to tribal broadband funding with CARES Act and the American Rescue Plan (ARPA) resources delivered new services in anticipation of campus networking planning and support.� The expectation to connect campuses to regional education and research networks was partially fulfilled through unexpected resource availability and with the assistance of tribal broadband leadership, in most cases.� Additional changes to the original project plan were the results of the significant deployment of federal broadband funding.�

�

A:shiwi College, Dine College and Tohono O�odham Community College redirected project resources from the initial homework gap wireless solutions to regional connectivity.� The Zuni and Tohono O�odham tribal utility organizations implemented both citizens band radio system (CBRS) and educational broadcasting services (EBS) for families, students, and the community.� Dine College contracted with Frontier, a recipient of CARES and ARPA funding for new fiber services to Tsaile, AZ to upgrade wireless services for student residences.� The project resulted in improving connectivity through new local and regional collaborations as well as the anticipated deployment of science specific networking at each campus.

�

Navajo Technical University intends to install campus networking equipment at each tribal college to complete the Tribal Consortium project.� The addition of added networking equipment and the CI engagement with campus faculty, the project delivered a series of successful outcomes for project collaborators, and it may be used as a model for other tribal colleges and universities, or for other resource restricted small campuses.
